instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message:
Hello,

I have light on charger, but no fan spin. 

Historic : Macbook was find in a dump, no fan spin but after cleaning the backlight keyboard connector it worked fine. I ultrasonic the board even if it looked clean, but 2 months later I have this problem.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,6V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 16,8V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = 0,9V, as <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.      
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is good

How can I find why I have a low voltage on this <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> ? I have no short on this.              

Thank you for your time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message:
That can't be even called low voltage; is missing.

What about <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PVH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and the 4 (four) PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3,42V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3,04V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3,12V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 2,50V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3,4V

I'm not sure about the 4 PCH's RTC signals you mean, but there is the following :
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 1,66V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 2,5V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3,27V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3,27V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 1,66V"
No good at all; probably accumulated crap underneath PCH.
Heat PCH area with quality flux; no more than 180-200 degress, for 20-30s.
If still low, try 330K instead of 1M for <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: Hi, I've tried first to heat PCH without any changes, then replace <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR> with a 330k, still no fan spin (no I have <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 2,5V)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: 2.5V is OK, but PCH can be bad...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: Do you think it worth the try to heat more the PCH ? I don't want to destroy it, more of that it could be something else than the PCH that I have no find yet...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message:
Only PCH is connected there.
Crap should be gone if you already heated at 200 degrees, but depends the flux used too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: I am using Amtech flux from Rossmann store so I reckon it's not crap flux :) and I cleaned the board twice in a ultrasonic cleaner so if crap was there it would be gone indeed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No fan spin
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
